title: Will phase 4 of the HH Sheikh Mohammed Bin Rashid Solar Energy Park be operational before 1 January 2021?
preds: Phase 3 came online in Nov 2020.  Phase 4 to begin operations in a staged programme from Q3 2021: https://www.constructionweekonline.com/projects-and-tenders/269080-mbr-solar-parks-800mw-phase-3-innovation-centre-begin-operations
http://wam.ae/en/details/1395302889658 article about inauguration of Phase 3 mentions Phase 4 but doesn't indicate it's imminent
No by the end of the year but very near, once Phase 3 is fully operational it is a matter of months.

First section of Phase IV complete.  Original commission date was scheduled for Q4 2020 - they seem to be on track. https://www.evwind.es/2020/09/24/abengoa-advances-in-the-construction-of-the-worlds-largest-concentrated-solar-power-complex-in-dubai/77352
https://www.arabianbusiness.com/energy/392294-sheikh-mohammed-launches-phase-4-of-giant-dubai-solar-park

Reducing continuously as long as there is no new information. Sources: [1] https://www.gjopen.com/comments/1085162
[2] https://mobile.twitter.com/DEWAOfficial/status/1278369312814891008
[3] https://www.dewa.gov.ae/en/about-us/media-publications/latest-news/2019/03/mohammed-bin-rashid-al-maktoum-solar-park
Correction to earlier forecast getting confused by translation of article from Chinese which was about phase 5. Phase 4 still very much possible for 2020 announcement.

The question will resolve based on information from the Dubai Electricity and Water Authority (DEWA), which tweeted that phase 4 will be commissioned starting in Q3 of 2021. [1] I requested clarification on what "operational" means (finished construction vs commissioned vs actually providing power to people). Unless operational refers to complete construction without any tests, there's no reason to think phase 4 will be operational by January 2021. I'm only leaving 10% in case I am wrong about this definition. [1] https://twitter.com/DEWAOfficial/status/1278369312814891008
I'm confused why the crowd is at 99% yet everyone who has posted an in-depth analysis is around 40%?? @RRG @Leifkj  what gives?
I forgot to allow for what ifs...

The question doesn't specify how much of the plant needs to be operational, since there supposedly are two parts to this phase 4 - a smaller PV array, and a larger CSP array.  The PV should be easy, though I haven't seen any specific status updates on it.
The CSP part gives me pause.  Wikipedia says there's a parabolic trough component, which I don't see mentioned elsewhere; maybe it's been dropped?  At any rate, troughs are a mature technology, and if it's not massively behind schedule, I wouldn't worry too much.
The power tower with molten salt storage, is a combination of two fairly new technologies in terms of installed capacity.  The most similar system in the US is Crescent Dunes, which has been a total debacle, and it's not like foreign firms have that much more experience either.  (Note: Crescent Dunes took two months to melt the salt in the storage system).  There are so many components to these systems, from the heliostats, to the power block, storage tanks, tower, receiver, cooling system, as well as all the general plumbing and electrical connections, and I don't think we've heard about any of them other than the tower and receiver.  Maybe that's because they're all going well, or are just too boring, or maybe not.
TL;DR - novel technologies, with shaky track record, lots of moving parts to go wrong.

Increasing my prediction for a Yes from 25% to 40%. Work has been going on over the last couple of months, the Molten Salt Receiver was recently installed.
- https://www.khaleejtimes.com/business/energy/molten-salt-receiver-installed-at-mohammed-bin-rashid-solar-park The above link also gives a good description of the project and its 4th phase.  I quote "The MSR is the centre and the most important part of the CSP plant. It receives solar radiation and turns it into thermal energy. Up to 50% of the overall project's first phase has been completed. This includes the solar power tower, the parabolic basin complex, and the photovoltaic solar panels. The fourth phase of the solar park combines CSP and photovoltaic technology and is rated for 950MW. It will use 700MW of CSP, 600MW from a parabolic basin complex, 100MW from the solar power tower and 250MW from photovoltaic solar panels." But also from the article "Al Tayer stated that the smoothness and continuity of construction work over the past period for this strategic project, despite the coronavirus pandemic. It has taken one and a half years to complete 60 per cent of the CSP tower and without injuries. The concrete part of the solar power tower is now complete at a height of 222 metres. The MSR was built and assembled while the tower was being built."
This is an outstanding project and will set an example to the world to follow in renewable energy.
First forecast. Hattip to @RRG for the background information [1]. [1] https://www.gjopen.com/comments/1038373

Through the international oil crisis the UAE leaders see the need for make a change in energy politics. Maybe a result of the corona pandemic crisis it will be that more and more people are working from home offices and need not to drive to work.
The progress of the fourth phase has not been disrupted due to the pandemic. With the agreements concluded for the fifth phase, the fourth phase will be completed by Jan 2021.

Reports show that they are ahead of schedule (although I can't find anywhere a target go live date.)  Based on the length of time it took Phase 3 to begin and first become operational, the fact that the final bits of Phase 3 are now complete as of April/May, looks like Phase 4 is on track to begin operations by year's end.  Leaving 10% out there since I can't find any reports stating either position.

Phase 3 was supposed to be operational in April 2020, but I have not seen any news reports of them going operational 
- https://gulfnews.com/photos/business/mohammed-bin-rashid-solar-park-phase-3-operational-in-april-1.1579363998709
- https://www.arabianbusiness.com/energy/437911-third-phase-of-giant-dubai-solar-park-to-go-online-in-april An overview of the MBR Solar Park can be found here - https://www.dewa.gov.ae/en/about-us/media-publications/latest-news/2019/03/mohammed-bin-rashid-al-maktoum-solar-park. Two points here are of particular importance:
- The fourth phase will use three technologies to produce clean energy: 600MW from a parabolic basin complex, 100MW from a concentrated solar tower, and 250MW from photovoltaic panels.
- The project was awarded to a consortium comprising Saudi Arabia’s ACWA Power, The Silk Road Fund, and China’s Shanghai Electric as the main contractor.  Both Saudi and the UAE would be facing funding issues ATM.  And checking Google Earth and Maps dont show any sign of a Solar Tower which has been built. The solar tower is an integral part of phase 4, a representation can be found here - https://www.protenders.com/companies/dubai-electricity-water-authority/projects/mohammed-bin-rashid-al-maktoum-solar-park-phase-4 Hence chances of being operational before 1st Jan 2021 seem to be low. Starting off with a baseline of 25%.

As the major part of the workload will actually be completed by foreign labor force, it depends on the future availability of employees and experts from abroad, whether or not large projects can progress as before. UAE as of today has a case rate of about 282 infections per 100,000 inhabitants, which lies near the lower bound for this number in nations of the Gulf region. Oman (146) and Saudi Arabia (198) lie below, Bahrain (443), Kuwait (545) and Qatar (1,473) lie well above this number, which indicates an uneven spread in the region due to individual national, social and other conditions, which may reduce or promote the community spread. Apart from differences in the intensity in testing, it may also, however, be a sign for a different timeline of the beginning of the pandemic in each state, with Qatar probably being affected at a very early stage. Thus, Qatar with its intense integration of foreign labor force in construction may be a blue print of the SARS-CoV-2 situation in the UAE in two to three weeks from now. With further increasing virus spread and more confirmed cases, foreign labor may decide to return to their home countries for safety reasons, or the afflux of new labor force may run dry for a couple of month, until the situation appears more clear, not to mention more practical difficulties in travel to and entering the UAE in the wake of travel restrictions and border control measures.  Also the delivery of essential material for assembly may be temporarily disrupted, as global supply chains are deranged. In all, there is a probability work cannot progress at the same rates as seen in the past.

Knee-jerk prediction, will investigate further:
Rationale being... again, deep pockets and favorable optics. Under current circumstances, a project in progress is a beast of its own. The global trend away from fossil fuel reliance and a cheap, reliable resource maximizes current mineral market profits. Being a global leader and authority on an innovation that renders your cash cow obsolete is a brilliant move.
